page.title: 22HEALTH CARE IN BUCHLYVIE
page.content:
Around 80% of Buchlyvie residents attend one surgery centrally located on Station Road adjoining the Village School. This Medical Centre was built in 2006 by Stirling District Council as a Community Build, one of the first in Scotland.

It is served by a team of four doctors, two practice nurses, two receptionist/dispensers, a health care assistant, midwife, district nurse, physiotherapist and podiatrist.

Other services available are Minor Surgery, Well-Woman Clinic, Well-Man Clinic, Diabetic Clinic, Travel Advice, Asthma Clinic, COPD (lung clinic), Healthy Heart Group and, once a year, a 'Flu Clinic.

The remainder of the residents attend practices in neighbouring villages.

For hospital services, patients must travel 15 or more miles. In 2011 Stirling Royal Infirmary closed for In-Patient care. It is now called Stirling Community Hospital and has various Out-Patient clinics and a Minor Injuries Unit, X-Ray Department and Out of Hours Service.

The new Forth Valley Royal Hospital at Larbert was opened by Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth in July 2011 for all In-Patient care and some Out-Patient Clinics.

Homecare for the elderly is organised by the village general practitioners in cooperation with Stirling District Council Social Work Department which supplies carers.

Pre-school children have all vaccinations and examinations done by the health visitor.

The Medical Centre also has a ‘Friends of Practice’ and a ‘Patient Participation Group’ which raise money to buy equipment for the Medical Centre and also arrange talks on various topics to do with health.

A wildlife garden established around the Medical Centre and the School is used as a joint resource.


Betty McLaren
